headline: Bank of American hates it employees, who aren't in management (except some of them)
pros:
I wish I could think of some, I guess having a job.
I had posirive vibes the last two years. weird how that works
cons:
We were told Bank of America is an "in the office company" which let's you know they do not give a care about their employees or how things have changed. Despite having better and more efficient production while at home during the last two years, Bank of America's management has decided you need to be in the office "just because" nevermind people still being afraid to come into work because of the virus, or rising gas prices. I guess someone's ego was being adversely impacted so they needed to make sure we capitulate. it is an absolutely tone deaf company, and does not give a hoot about the employees' welfare. HR is inept too, the stuff I know would make people cringe. 

I literally know people posting out of jobs to take less money and less stress within the bank. Management is either clueless or gutless Moynihan is tone deaf. People rather give up their position than deal with the ineptitude of management.

headline: Decent pay and benefits,  stuck in Stone Age for flexible work options
pros: Pay, benefits and training have been more than decent. Feel appreciated for the work completed and knowledge gained.
cons: Management, all the way up to the CEO is stuck in the past on flexible work arrangements. Ironic because they pioneered a WFH program in mid-2000s that was great. Everyone needs to be in a seat in a building, even non-customer facing. Applying for jobs is painful if not in a “core” location, even as a tenured employee, to advance your career. “If the location isn’t listed, too bad” kind of mentality. Their knowledge leaving with their tenured employees to more flexible companies. Oh well. I’m considering doing the same.

headline: Good Company to Work for
pros: BofA is a good company to work for. My department was within CCA, or Consumer Credit Assistance. The job itself wasn't hard as it was mostly report validation and working with other stakeholders on analyzing strategies.
cons:
The problem is that no one seems to know what data to use, it's a royal pain to get access to anything, and there's not much upward mobility.

It seems that your only real shot at climbing the ladder is to already get a job pretty high up the ladder at BofA. If you want a good job with decent pay and don't care about that then sure an AVP role isn't bad.

headline: Good benefits, toxic culture.
pros: The pay at the bank is decent. Somewhat lower than other institutions but overall not horrible. The benefits such as vacation and sick time is generous.
cons:
The company uses a top down control method to the extreme. The c-suite level managers are interested in micromanaging lower level employees. This is due to every line of business I’m currently aware of not having the option of working from home. The company also punishes the employee for not having certain vaccines. Sadly, they make healthcare more expensive. Why not add additional incentives for these procedures instead of making something like our healthcare costs more expensive? Also, at my office, the bank does not help with employee parking charges. This is around $180 a month.

Sadly, once you are salary, you are typically asked to work 50 hours week. I have seen cases upwards of 70 hours for 4 months straight, working 6-7 days a week depending on the season. Although you have great vacation benefits, the bank makes it difficult to use it all due to the workload they give you. If you leave on vacation, you will typically fall behind with only slight assistance from others to catch up.

headline: Contact Center > Branch Worker
pros:
Contact Center: 5 day work week, competitive pay with bonuses, good benefits
Branch Banker: Less of a 1984 vibe. You are trusted to have honest conversations with customers rather than each word of your dialogue being analyzed by QA agents.
cons:
Contact Center: As I alluded to above, every conversation you have, every click you make is carefully and closely monitored. They screen workers very carefully to ensure they are trustworthy, but will HAMMER you for the slightest slip up in the script. 

Branch Banker: Relentless and absurd levels of abuse from customers 6 days a week. The people who still regularly use branch banking are the most entitled and arrogant people you can possibly imagine.

headline: Decent - but suffers from significant infrastructure issues
pros:
Decent London environment
Sales/Trading desks are well resourced
Support teams are sound
Good on-site facilities (gym/canteen)
cons:
Mad politics - especially between London office and the mothership - US, and between London and Paris. Difficult to navigate in order to further career without being drawn into taking sides/crazy amount of lip service.
Ageing infrastructure - risk and booking systems need enhancement. Makes simple every day things much harder - noticeable with most companies that did not grow its tech organically (BofA's acquisition of ML).

headline: Making a shambles with their lack of flexible working
pros: It's a great corporate culture with many benefits, and for most teams you find the senior leaders to be personable.
cons: The are really making a mess of their "office based company" messaging, while most other companies on the street have clear and strong messaging about their flexibile working offerings, BofA appear to be stuck in the 20th century. With the messaging from the board that we are office based, and then not enough seats in the office for all the staff, it's unofficially necessary for people on teams to WFH while the top down messaging is that people are expected in the office 5 days a week.

headline: There's a lot good people who work there but senior leadership is stuck in the stone-age
pros: Great benefits, good career mobility, decent salary, decent training.
cons:
Limited transparency on pay. 

Limited transparency on career pathing.

Anti-work from home

Limited flexibility with scheduling when it's not convenient for the company.

Lip service on real changes.

Inconsistent resource allocation for departments across the enterprise.

Inconsistent communication between departments across the enterprise.

One item that sticks out for me regarding remote work, is with all the work from home infrastructure in place the company has decided employees can work at home for a snow day, or other inclement weather event instead of shutting down the building. BUT employees do not have the same option for a childcare issue or health concerns. It's all one-way, in the companies favor.

headline: Great Bank in Need of Complete HR Overhaul
pros: Bank holidays, nice brand on resume.
cons: The Bank is in serious trouble if they don’t to an overhaul of their talent acquisition team. High expectations with a low patience threshold, employees are dumped on with unreasonable workloads, zero lead times on tight turn arounds, little to no support, new staff have to train themselves and are sent to websites for answers, there aren’t enough seats in the Charlotte office, so you may be working one week and then get sent home another, and zero work life balance. This place has been so hard on my mental health, I am now on anxiety meds. Save yourself. There’s a reason why there are 14k openings here.

headline: The absolute worst
pros: FADP was great not MFSA.
cons: They lie to you. At first you keep your clients. Then a week later nope they are gone. They say you get good leads. No they all suck for the most part. Calling the same people 9 times isn’t a good lead. Then you get the report of how many calls you’ve made. They don’t care if you generate business you better not have a 15 minute gap between calls or you’ll get a nasty email. It’s beyond micromanaging. I had a lunch appointment with a prospect opened 300k account and got chewed out because I wasn’t making calls. Priorities are wrong and market leaders don’t have a clue what to do. Just call all day and if you don’t get an account call night next week. Worst environment ever. It was great before the switch.

headline: Employee Overall Well-Being/Work-Life Balance is Not Valued
pros: Good benefits if you have a family: childcare reimbursement, elderly care, maternity/paternity leave, adoption expense assistance
cons:
The 2% "cost of living raise" does not cover COL at all. Most employees are spending 50% of their paycheck on housing, if not more.

Removing work-from-home options after 2 years for "company culture" is heartbreaking for employees and their families. Especially with gas prices the way they are, this commute plus all the in-office expenses of having to buy work clothes, hand sanitizer, masks that actually work, extra car maintenance, etc. is creating a scenario where most employees are taking a sizeable pay cut.

Not to mention how bad commuting is for the mental health and environment of your employees. 

Other banks are offering more work from home/hybrid options and better pay--and many employees here are actively weighing their options to leave for elsewhere or retire. People are already on-edge and moods are notably down because of this change. Offering extra counseling sessions isn't enough.

headline: Politics, Low salary, Low Hikes, No Growth
pros: Only a brand name. That to logically BA continuum (non-bank subsidiary), not Bank of America
cons:
Have nice policies on paper, but they are only for US. Like 4 month paternity (10days for India), People manager will use your ideas for their own growth, Extream level of favouritism, Stocks as success reward/bonus (18-20k annual bonus for India), 20-30% annual growth (3-10% hike in India), Very big pay disparity (Eg-200 crore annual salary to CEO Mr Brian, 31% hike in 2021, India employees get peanuts), No welcome gift in form of Joining kit etc. (I joined in lockdown, received 10 pieces of Mask and one sanitizer, it made my roommates laugh on me), unsupportive Indian management (I purchased laptop to work from home at my own and then have to wait for 11 months for reimbursement) 
In short, it's only a name which can give you feeling of working in a big brand, otherwise nothing at India office is worth to mention as benefits for BOA.

cons: HIGH sales pressure! I consistently hit numbers and was still demanded to do more, even if it is at the expense of the customer. Pay is bottom tier for what you will be responsible for. Unless you buy fully in to the BOA culture, which at the branch level is BOA only has solutions and every single client better use our "solutions," don't expect any promotions.

headline: Wouldn’t recommend long term
pros: Since they constantly refuse to hire staff once someone quits you learn your job pretty quickly if you keep up with the workload, which could later be useful for a future career. You will learn quick in technology (will explain in cons)
cons: Never updated branch, our roof literally caved in during a storm, everything is broken and doesn’t work including the systems. Marketing just likes to add more products to push you to sell which then leads to system malfunction because it can’t handle all the patchy technology. Every single customer I helped my system crashed, so you have to remember how to speak to the system. Because it won’t speak to you. Corporate doesn’t listen or care about in branch employees. Decided to delete my raise when they (increased minimum wage)

headline: Downhill spiral
pros:
*Learned the industry from the ground up 
*Developed a wide range of skills both directly connected to my role and far beyond typical job description 
*Worked with absolutely fantastic people 
*Decent compensation
*Historically fair work life balance
cons:
*Executive leadership is out of touch with both the front line units, and how to effectively run the business
*Extremely stagnant career path once leadership is achieved (no real promotion opportunities)
*Phony double speak about sales environment - executives place excessive sales pressure on team managers yet hamstring one’s ability to drive team in a meaningful way (also require us to attest to ‘not receiving sales pressure’ which is a bold faced lie) I have zero problem with being held to results, but some expectations are wellsfargo 2.0
*Business controls is more focused on whether or not our 800 disclosures are read on every call instead of addressing the above sales pressure issue 
*Senior leadership doesn’t care about the associate experience at all 
*There is zero feedback loop between FLUs and executives to be able to address / resolve issues
*Providing constructive feedback to attempt to innovate or improve are viewed as ‘not buying into the vision’ 
*Countless check the box routines that do nothing to drive business forward

headline: There is now better out there
pros:
BOA at this time/in this job market is best suited for - 
1. Entry-Level / First job 
2. An External candidate looking to make a move from a competing company due to stagnant career growth
3. Internal employee whom is close to Retirement

* This is not the company you stay with as a B4-B5 level in the the middle of your career - companies will pay you significantly more to join them. You can always return (or not) in a few years, be in a higher pay range and gain great experience.
Pros:
1. Great benefits for employees who make under 100k a year.
2. Loved the employees I worked with.
3. Great work/life balance (LOB dependent).
4. Great PTO/Sick Time.
cons:
1. Expensive Benefits if over $100k salary - in comparison to competitors.
2. Lack of transparency/ease of mobility for internal applicants: 
A. Internal job postings do not provide any pay details/ranges. 
B. Band System (Role hierarchy) provides little value. 
3. Bonus is a joke. No start or target amount/%, it is a complete surprise. Bonuses were handed out to brand new employees (under 90 days) for same $ as existing/established employees. Bonuses average for B5 employees at 3-4% of salary. HR tells you 10-15% and this has not been the case amongst co-workers. (This of course is LOB dependent - other LOBs may operate differently)
4. Remote options and hybrid work schedules are not encouraged or promoted (don’t ask/don’t tell). Bank monitors and reports how long you utilize VPN. Return to Office has been in existence since Summer of 2021.
5. Parking is an added expense in CLT.

headline: Outdated, Mismanaged, and Hopeless
pros: Insurance and flexible WFH Schedule
cons:
Onboarding team was generally mismanaged and neglected to the point of stagnation. High turnover rate, extremely low morale, old/outdated systems, poor communication, unnecessarily elongated onboarding processes. 

Repeatedly told process improvements are in the pipes and told to wait while the only process improvements implemented are for higher ups to pad metrics that are useless. 

 You will be heavily reliant on other teams/co-workers to move things forward, and will always be at your expense if you’re not hounding teammates to complete the work. 

Career opportunities are essentially “work until you drop out and go to a different team. “

Insurance benefits are nice, but HR is generally useless and is not responsive to inquiries.

Your role will have you being 7 teams at once, when drowning with work management “listens” and forgets as soon as the call is over.

Work/Life balance is frowned upon, working OT/ past 7-8pm was the norm to STAY ON TRACK with the work.

headline: Big/bureaucratic, old school bank with less competitive pay but good work/life balance (at least in Charlotte)
pros:
-Most roles outside investment and corporate banking are pretty much 9-5
-Corporate culture is very rah-rah, meaning a desire to win in the market and be loyal to BofA. Many folks have worked here most of their lives so you can build a strong personal brand and network
-Very risk-management focused (the Bank learned lessons from the Great Recession) so you don't really have to worry about seeing the company in the news for compliance issues or other shady things
-The bank is huge and loves to hire from within. Practically, this means if you network well you can have different jobs (or careers, really) in different lines of business without leaving the bank.
-Technological capabilities are pretty good; you feel like you have the tools you need to do your job
-Generally very good health insurance (pretty much free meds from pharmacy, good co-pay rates for doctors and reasonable deductibles)
-Pretty lax with tracking vacation time; as long as you get your work done, take time off when you need to
cons:
-Human Resources (HR) and their recruiting and on-boarding processes are embarrassingly horrendous. HR can be brusque, lazy, and completely unaware of how to place people in the right roles. Be VERY careful with whomever your HR rep is, and push back if you're getting a bad feeling about them. Once they place you somewhere and you've signed your contract you will be screwed if you didn't make sure to look out for yourself very diligently. HR is an incompetent gatekeeper with too much power on its hands.
-Stingy when it comes to base salary and bonuses, especially in comparison to its peers in the industry. In addition, BofA seems to pinch pennies on business expenses (e.g. watches price tags very closely for business travel, vendor costs, "extras", such as employee blackberries, etc.). Also has a policy of maintaining/not altering employee salaries if you happen to move to a more expensive city. As such, be VERY sure about what city you choose to be placed in, as whatever salary you get there, that's what it will be. Meaning, if you get a role in Charlotte and later decide you want to transfer to New York City, Chicago, LA, etc. the Bank will NOT pay for a cost of living adjustment. You'll take your same Charlotte salary with you.
-Very bureaucratic and tons of red tape. It can sometimes feel like you are actually working for the government vs. the private sector. This has its pluses in that you can have a good work/life balance without intense stress all the time because you can fly under the radar or at least not be scrutinized daily (at least outside investment and corporate banking, i.e. consumer and everywhere else), but it also means you have to be VERY proactive about building your career or you can fall through the cracks, be bored to death, and have your skills atrophy. This is more for Charlotte; it seems the New York City offices are higher intensity and more efficient, which of course makes sense culturally.

headline: Attention to Detail, Fast Pace!
pros:
As a relationship banker, you are managing clients coming in to see a banker or have appointments. You must have good time management skills to fit in clients. 
Even if you’re a relationship banker, you have to do teller transactions to cover tellers who are break or if the line is overly crowded. Teller transactions must be clearly focused, otherwise you can mess up a transaction or lose money in your cash box. Mostly a relationship banker job is to make sure if the person who you are dealing with is not acting upon someone else. So you must read documents very carefully on accounts to proceed with transactions.
cons: They are irate clients on a daily basis. You must have patience or know how to control the situation. Management is very harsh on sales, and you may feel over worked by being a banker and teller at the same time.

headline: Great Company to Work for, but Areas for Improvement
author_position: Vice President; Senior Business Control Specialist
pros: -Good benefits: 4 months paid paternity leave, 4 weeks of vacation, tuition reimbursement ($5250 tax free and $1750 taxable for total of $7500 annually), premium healthcare options, stock options, 5% 401k match, 2% annual employer 401k contribution, Preferred Rewards Platinum benefits as employee, paid holiday and sick time, and other benefits.
cons:
- Functional silos. Any cross functionality between departments you will have to proactively engage. Different areas have different metrics/incentives, which can cause conflict if you are trying to improve processes. Ex. Sales motivated by sales metrics (leads, new referrals, new money, # of accounts opened, customer survey scores, etc.). Operations/Compliance motivated by risk mitigation, taking time to perform reviewed (adding to lead times), back and forth on documentation and procedures.
- Positions do not list salary pay range. You have to do your due diligence to research and ask people willing to share their salary. And you have to negotiate with HR during hiring process. Annual pay increases are determined based on performance rating given by management during annual review and compensation increases decided by management. Limited room for any negotiation.
- Positions that are not client facing and can be done remotely are limited. Company wants employees to work in office, even if not client facing.
- Limited funding for process improvement for workflows, resulting in manual processes and mundane work that could be automated.

headline: Stable salary, not a great working environment
pros: Bank of America provides training and support needed to make you successful in your role. There are also many opportunities to move up into higher paying roles. Depending on what department you work in, the work environment is very different. There is a strong sense of community within the different departments and teams.
cons: The work is very sales oriented in most positions offered, even in service roles. If you are having trouble with your sales numbers, they will offer you support to help you improve. But if you're in a role that you don't enjoy and your sales numbers are not good, it is much more difficult to move to a different (non-sales based) role. When I was working there, I felt more like a number and less like a person.

They want everyone to waste time on stupid behaviors that take away from anything productive. Culture is pretty hit or miss depending on who you are working for. I can’t imagine working here for more than 5 years it is exhausting. The lack of support and micro management are a killer.

headline: Understaffed and Underpaid
pros: Honestly, I preferred being a janitor or working fast food.
cons:
Financial centers are run on skeleton crews, which means you have to do multiple people's jobs.
Company moving to a model of making most employees responsible for most aspects of the financial center (teller, operations, sales, etc.) but not paying as much as they did for 'higher' positions that they no longer fill. 
Company unable to retain quality employees, which leaves unqualified people in management and sales positions. This leads to a lot of legal and policy grey areas or out right violations.
Benefits are a joke.

headline: Bank Of America
pros: Good company to work for
cons: Long hours to work everyday

headline: Avoid if you can
pros: -good canteen (though quite expensive) with great staff going above and beyond to serve good food and dishes; they also prepare special dishes/cakes for Halloween etc.
cons:
-salary increase falls short of inflation,
-shares instead of monetary incentive that could be invested elsewhere,
-mild culture of xenophobic attitudes (mocking someone's English by repeatedly mentioning the mistake they make or used to make, making jokes based on race/ethnicity...) with no reaction after incidents were reported or raised as an issue,
-very little diversity at a senior level (almost all are white straight British men),
-limited career progression opportunities,
-poor office facilities (too few cleaners combined with some messy colleagues in a busy office),
-no remote work options,
-poor handling of the pandemic (denial in first two months, poor adherence to pandemic, no monitoring of rule adherence amongst employees...),
-senior management trying to ban discussion of salaries amongst staff,
-salary bands/levels are not transparent,
-you may occasionally get asked about doing something that is unlawful or unethical (I reported these few occasions to the police and received support from there),
-poor environmental commitment (EV subsidy not available for most electric cars, office using powerful greenhouse gas as an insulator, the pension scheme does not have an option to invest in decarbonised funds...),
-the bank funded an award event for a far right politician Jair Bolsonaro while claiming to support BAME and LGBT communities.

headline: Great Company to work for

Absolutely love their employee benefits with First time home buying financial help or, even going back to college offering almost 7.500 per year (up to 5,250 tax free) for tuition assistance per year.
cons: College hire/students who come with not much of IT experience is underpaid from the avg market rate. It takes years to prove yourself in the teams and is a slow increment process. headline: Good if You Have a Good Market Leader
pros: Train you to obtain licenses. Working in a branch gives you access to leads. In the past, if you have a good relationship with your branch everyone can kill it. But now, one team referral credit is gone, you compete with RMs, difficult to get leads. Average to above average benefits. If you have a good manager, it can be a great place to start a financial career.
cons: Some managers can be good, but the majority only view you as a number. If you have a bad manager, they will micromanage (policy reminders, letter of educations... ) and be a slave driver. If you hit 80% to goal they threaten you. If you hit 100% to goal, they say the expectation is 150% to goal. If you hit 200% to goal, they don't acknowledge it. Some managers can also test your ethics asking you to do shady stuff. If you tell them no, they will tell you that you wont hit your numbers.

Great Health insurance, 401k match.
If you get hired into a good team with a good manager there is a good work life balance, low stress, good communication about the future and career goals. During the pandemic they provided ppe, onsite covid testing, option to work from home, lunch was provided for in office people for almost 2 years.
cons:
If you get in a team with a disorganized manager it will make moving up or laterally kind of difficult. 
Networking is the most important thing when trying to make a career move

headline: High quality pay, low growth potential, low bonuses, mind numbing work

headline: Great company that does care. Life changer.
pros: Work hours are similar to office hours. Some branches only open M-F. It's the closest job to an office job. Closed on national holidays (lots of time off!) Low stress. Great work and life balance. Employer requires you stay away from the computer to take full breaks and work 40 hours. They also do not force you to sell like other places do. Management is communicative, receptive, and professional. 5-star training academy. Positive environment. Talents do not go unnoticed. Opportunity for individual and career growth.
cons: Starting pay might be low or average depending on where you come from. But once in, plenty of room for growth and decently good pay as you earn your incentives or move up. Like any workplace, there may be a coworker who doesn't like you/who won't do their share of work or a manager who micromanages but that depends on your luck. Most people I met were mature and helpful.

headline: Company Culture and Ethics

BOA is very good company with wonderful culture and Ethics.
Compensation wise it provides good hike and good salary.
Give value to the associates and customer
BOA invest lot of learnings and technologies.
We can gain lot of Banking domain knowledge and learn various technologies.
cons:
Few project have no Vision, it will be very delay.
No parental health insurance from company, we need to pay.
No systematism or discipline in leadership.
BOA is number one with competitors in Banking, but from technical learning perspective it is completely different model and way of doing, so technical associates and we cannot compete with outside market. For exm, they say SRE model, but BOA is not following.

headline: Shell of what it used to be - now only for the "Woke"
pros: I personally get paid well for my position, but when your review is 'exceeds' and you only receive a 2% raise (when the company just had record growth), I know I'm being punished/held back so others in same role can catch up. I like my direct manager and the teams I support, but I have no control over when all that changes (and it does change often). Entry level positions will be starting at $25/hr by 2025, currently at $21.
cons: Everyone is extremely unhappy right now with raises/bonuses and there is a mass exodus, but company doesn't care. All decisions and actions are now based on the color of your skin, your vax status and your personal pronouns. No rhyme or reason to why some get promoted to management, other than playing favorites...so you will likely work under someone who should never be managing people. On my team, 2 VERY deserving females were passed over for promotions and given to 2 males (1 of which does NOT deserve it at all)...and this was done by a female manager.

headline: My experience
pros:
It is a regular job of being thrown into software that is outdated, resolving issues usually related to VPN they have transitioned into a new database for resolving issues and it’s a step back. Systems are out dated, they use Internet Explorer and trying to transition to Edge

People say it is all about the benefits, you get health insurance, 401k and 3 weeks paid time off and 10 days of sick leave, every company does that
cons:
-Managememt knows less than the employees if you request assistance keep in mind both of you are scratching your heads.


- They nag on you for doing your work and expect some immaculate speed from you, and if you are phased by this then.. hope for the best.

-They offered me a 0.67 raise and some stock options as a bonus. I laughed really hard considering BOA made 8.3 trillion in last quarter. You will get the bottom of the barrel as far as income.

- if you expect growth, you will not find it here.

headline: Obsessed with RTO
pros: Works for you if you’re privileged and white
cons:
Performative in hiring. Hires poc and then doesn’t invest in development resources so all are left unsatisfied but they can say they hired x number poc. They provide a lot of money to the outside community and then don’t give the best compensation internally. 

EOY reviews are structured in a way that creates a good old boy environment.

During one of their most profitable years we were still wfh, yet there is a massive push that BOA has an “in office culture”. Many employees do not want to RTO and yet it is still being pushed.

They don’t care about the great resignation, DE&I or employee satisfaction.

headline: Awesome company
pros: Awesome place to work, and good benefits
cons: Hard to grow under the control of management

headline: Fantastic company… conflicted about the future
pros: Solid company, strong brand, pays well, incredible benefits, great management team, so many avenues for promotion and development, rewarding work
cons: The bank continues to go “woke” and the CEO is a major player in the World Economic Forum, which is bad news. Really wish he wasn’t hob knobbing with globalist elites with nefarious agendas.

headline: AVOID AVOID AVOID
pros: Big company so the odds of them going out of business or being acquired are very low. Medical benefits are fine since they are so big.
cons: It's not about doing good work at the bank, it's about being "good friends" with the leadership team. They promote based on who they are friends with. Year end reviews are pointless. Even if you do your work at a satisfactory level, if you're ranked below your peers, you won't get a raise or bonus, which goes back to being good friends with senior leadership. Raises on average are 2-3 percent, which is WAY below the inflation rate and raise of competitors. They give you stock options but they don't vest for 4 years, which means you don't get anything that first year. One of the worst companies I've worked for and I would not recommend anything working here.

headline: Doesn’t compensate for overworked expectations
pros: Good benefits, time off, dental and healthcare
cons: Low pay raises. Expect employees to take on work of more than 1 peer when out of office and not compensated for it.

headline: Opportunities

cons: Nothing I can say now

headline: Exceptional company
pros: I've had an incredible journey so far in my career with this company. The culture is demanding yet I've had the flexibility to maintain a reasonable work life balance. I've worked for different types of managers and while some did not align with my personality, I've had many who did. Great benefits and fair pay with lots of opportunity for diversity and inclusion. Overall I've enjoyed this company and have reaped the benefits. There is childcare reimbursements that helps with costs of daycare, tuition reimbursement, vacation, sick time and pto, 401k and financial education.
cons: There is a lot of change as far as regulatory and organizational restructuring which is typical for this industry. It requires someone who embraces change and can quickly pivot from one project to another. While it can be rewarding, you may experience burnout if you do not pace yourself. I've known some people who have had a terrible time in their roles due to bosses who create toxic workplaces. There is a minimum time frame required to move to a different team. If you can wait out that requirement, you have a whole world of other opportunities that you can apply for.

headline: Thoughtful and caring companies are hard to find.
pros:
Incredible benefits package.
You're treated like a valued member.
The company cares about social initiatives.
Great training and continued development.
High expectations and accountability.
Open door policy and feedback accepted from the top down.
Diversity MATTERS!
So much more....
cons:
Leadership changes too often.
Staffing levels can create many challenges. 
Employees are constantly moved to different lines of business making it hard to manage your talent bench and maintain consistent performance.
Goals for the different lines of business make it very difficult to keep the same message.
Over the last few years (during the pandemic) clients have become increasingly more hostile and aggressive.
The ability to cross over into a different line of business or be promoted is very dependent on your networking abilities.

headline: Caring about HOW not just WHAT
pros:
There are many good things I could say about my decade at B of A. A key differentiator: beyond their (very high) expectations for results, they actually care about HOW people behave and do their work. It's even part of their performance review goals. 

The culture in my mortgage domain was collegial, collaborative, and positive. I'd do it again!
cons: The intensity and pace of work was high. They value and expect a constant sense of urgency. Depending on your role or project, that was sometimes energy-draining.

headline: Good people, but bureacratic and not open to remoting
pros: Most of the people I have worked with have a high amount of integrity and professionalism, which is probably the best reason to work anywhere. Benefits are pretty comprehensive.
cons: Very bureaucratic, which makes it difficult to get things done efficiently. No remoting or even hybrid without special medical clearance. Promotions are rare, so most employees end-up stuck where they are.

headline: Super conscientious-- defines "professional"

Like other big banks, it emphasizes "work from the office"

headline: Student Part-Timer
pros:
Great Benefits that extend beyond the general Insurance and PTO scene. Two examples consist of sponsoring sessions with a Therapist/Counselor and emergency funding support that is reviewed on a case by case basis.

They recently announced a minimum wage increase to $21 USD/Hour. 

I had the pleasure of meeting some of the best people who are now some of my closest friends after I departed the company. 

I liked the involvement they had with communities and universities. There were several events that I volunteered for on behalf of the company.

I believe working with the company would be a great introduction and/or job for a University student. 

Overall, I believe Bank of America is a great company to work at.
cons: There are concerns with staffing, but that occurred during the start of the pandemic and may have lingering effects.

headline: Good company if are looking for benefits
pros: Benefits are good and good work/life balance
cons: If you enjoy being a software engineer this isn't the company for you. This company is more for people who don't want to have to work that hard and get lost in the red tape. They are trying to be a modern tech company but have a long way to go.

headline: Hostile Environment and Leadership and High Turnover of Employees
pros: Banking hours are great when they allow you to be staffed which is rare.
cons: Employees have no voice. Managers are micromanaged down to their own employees schedules, etc. High turnover in staff constantly leaving branches understaffed and new employees thrown in undertrained. Lack of visibility from Market Leaders, but threatening emails, and calls are never ending. Family and life outside of the bank is not important to leaders. Hostile work environment and all employees are extremely overworked and exhausted. Change is good in the workplace, but never being comfortable is not ok. Worrying about having a banker at all in your branch was constant. Often branches are left with new management and a new team leaving little experience available to customers. Those with experience are often interrupted to assist the inexperienced. Not a good experience for clients or an employees confidence. Just a messy place to work. Left feeling guilty if you or your child is sick, or gosh forbid an employee have a personal matter.

headline: False Advertising
pros: Amazing Medical Insurance Benefits Only
cons: They hire you for one location then after you’re hired they send you anywhere else they want on a moments notice. You can work for the company for almost a decade and they dispose of you like trash. You can ask managers and employee relations and HR for help and they don’t care. When you call voicing frustrations that the place you have been transferred to, unwillingly, is 2 hours round trip from home & the commute is causing unnecessary stress on you & your family, they tell you to see a therapist or a doctor to find out how to deal with it. Branch can have no toilet & they tell you you will have to drive across the street to go at the grocery store. Told management there was a strong smell of propane/gas in a back closed door room (that we used all day and had to keep the door closed while we were using it and the bank is open for business ), for a year and a half, only to find out later after something else needed fixing that there were not 1 but 2 gas leaks. Asked a manager one time if I could go pump as a nursing mother with a newborn at home & was told I had to wait quite some time (Even though there was plenty of staff coverage for me to use my required lunch break to do this), while I was in pain and about to leak through my shirt. Employees that were a known close contact & in the presence of another positive employee, are not required to submit a negative test upon return to the branch and only needed to take 2 -3 days off. At the beginning of the pandemic the bank allowed people who were “high risk” or had “high risk” family to stay at home getting paid for doing nothing, then were trained to work in the call center department from home, while the rest of us (including people with high risk family who didn’t know they could call and work from home), were torn from our home branches and forced to drive all over the place so far from home in branches so crowded with angry customers there was no way to socially distance anywhere. This was under the guise that we would be going back to our branch however now they’ve started closing them permanently and not working with the employees to find them a place closer to home or they shuffle people even further away without asking. We are forced to wear bank provided masks (that are not KN95 which are supposed to be the most effective). The bank slogan of “we’re better when we’re connected” is a sham. There has never been more disconnect between employees and management and employee relations than there is now. Given the current worldly events, this is extremely disheartening. This bank does not care about employees even the employees who have put in so many years of their life, dedication and talents and spent so many hours away from their families commuting to and fro. Beware.

headline: Great company! Tough goals....
pros:
-Bank of America is a great place to work. I really believe that they have the best and brightest in retail branch banking working for them in the financial centers and throughout the leadership team they have in Philadelphia. If you end up in that market be sure to find a market leader to connect with and mentor you. You'll learn and grow a lot. 

-Their training is top notch. They really focus on providing great learning resources. They make it really easy to navigate the workplace and serve bank clients their.

-The benefits are the best I've ever seen at a bank

-After working for 3 different retail banks in the Philadelphia area, it's clear that Bank of America is way ahead of the game with technology.

-If you are serious and all in on building a career in banking, I think Bank of America is great place to be. I've seen my co workers take on plenty of responsibilities outside of the RM role that provided career growing experiences and exposure leading to promotions.
cons:
Some of your success depends on the branch you're located. I was moved around a couple of times. At one branch I was at over 150% to goal for the quarter and got a big quarterly bonus. At other branches I'd be under 30% to goal, prepping my "the reason they let me go speech" for my co-workers and back here on Glassdoor comparing salaries for the next job.

The weekly outbound calling target for each RM was too much. The script to do it was very weak. Without an effective script and/or the flexibility for an RM to have a real conversation with someone outside of it (due to bank policies on outbound calls), making calls everyday was almost a complete waste of time.

-You will be micromanaged. There is a metric and target for every activity in the branch. The pressure to hit every single behavioral target is intense and can be off putting at times.

headline: Not the best work environment
pros: - $200 Disaster pay for a while during Covid-19 and free lunch for a while.
cons:
- The culture of BOA is strictly sales… managers are very desperate when it comes to meeting their goals which makes for a very hostile work environment and not genuine to clients.

- They had me as a part time 30hr employee but expected me to work 40+ hrs a week… but did not receive full time benefits (such as full time PTO, etc.)

- Employees are heavily over worked and the company does not send extra help or hire when necessary.

- I relocated during my time at BOA and the Branch Manager and Market Leader refused to transfer me to a location closer to my house because it would be a loss to them. My commute was 70 miles per day with no mileage compensation until I finally resigned after 9 months of making this commute. 

- No sense of family or genuine team bonding

pros:

cons:
When I was working the total project knowledge is know by a single resource.  No proper Documentation to even go through or have self training.
No proper KT is arranged by the new manager who was appointed to handle multiple projects in which was included the one I am working. The manager is completely non technical unable to understand minimum technical terminology like SIT/Dev env and highly dependent on the single resource who has the project details who had been quite some time in the project. 
The work environment is so bad that the single resource has the ability to bad mouth /yelling the new comers and can do whatever he can. Manager has nothing to do with. when they are recruiting they did not even mention that it is a L3 support project and which made my stay more difficult since we need to support the release during weekend .Manger forced me to come on weekends despite my request several times not to do that. Also there is lot of support and appreciation given to vendor resources in the project. All I can observe is Manager and the single resource had placed lot of pressure on me so that I would be leaving the project and they want to replace my place with some new vendor resource.Finally I have resigned and then I got in touch with HR during exit interview and explained the situations which made me to do so.
I was really shocked to see the working environment in BACCI so pathetic which is quite different from the projection I saw outside. So was placing this review to help other new joiners to be careful .

headline: Only 3 stars because of the pay and benefits…
pros:
1. Very competitive for the location
2. Great benefits package!
3. Decent work/life balance
4. The bank is starting to modernize their tech stack by introducing a version of Vue that sits on their internal framework. It is slowly starting to transform from their more internal framework to more “plain old” Vue than the internal framework, which is good thing to IMO since Vue offers a far superior developer experience.
5. Programmers start to get yearly bonuses in 2022 along with restricted stock units as well or so I’ve been told.

To be frank, of my job didn’t pay what it pays and didn’t make use of a modern UI framework like React or Vue then I would not be working here. I suspect the same from a lot of others!
cons:
1. Many areas of bank are still using the banks’ internal framework. IMO, It’s not very intuitive, is very clunky and slow, and thus difficult to develop on. Anti patterns are found everywhere and it all stems from their internal framework. More than that, it’s not really like anything else that is that a modern UI developer would already be familiar with, so those skills won’t be transferable to other jobs. Therefore, your skills will not translate to BofA’s internal stack either. I HIGHLY recommend making sure that you are working on a job that uses Vue or React so you don’t have to worry about your skills becoming useless to the market at large should you ever choose to leave.

2. They are not 100% work from home even though there is no good reason for devs to work in the office. They are somewhat flexible though, but most days you’ll need to be in the office. However, if you need a day here or there per month to work at home then you typically can.

3. They banks security software is insanely strict. They have even blocked stack overflow for god’s sake! I mean WTF, right? If you are in the states then you can still get access but if you are not then you absolutely not get access to SO whatsoever on the banks proxy server which is very stupid IMO. I wish they’d get called out publicly over this and change this god awful rule.

4. Documentation of internal tooling is very scarce. Even the docs to get your environment setup was “half-assed”. Probably by some employees who got tired of helping everyone but didn’t have time to make proper documentation. In other areas in the back, it only gets worse… much, much worse. This needs a drastic overhaul because it’s a freakishly easy fix.

5. For the reasons above, I definitely get the feeling that the software engineers are still second class citizens at the bank despite the fact that more and more people now days set up bank accounts entirely online. The feeling I get is that they aren’t interested in making top quality products, but that they are more like “hey let’s get us some of those software people to make some stuff we need to stay competitive in the digital age”, only they do slightly more than the bare minimum. That said, it’s still definitely better than most other SWE jobs simply because of the massive resources that they have. I wouldn’t worry too much about this for more than 10 years or so because Ally Financial is completely online and is now BofAs main competitor in Charlotte, and they actually do treat their software engineers like first class citizens despite the fact they have far less resources than BofA at this time. Like I said, that will even out in the near future though. Especially if BofA doesn’t get on the ball and start making everything with updated UI technology.

6. The developer onboarding experience is terrible. Please fix it. You should have new hires monitored very closely for the first three months regardless of their skill level with coding. There needs to be some sort of mentoring program started too!!

headline: Honest Review of 5-year stint with positives and negatives
pros:
Solid benefits, great exposure, for a bank - a strong brand and community reputation, philanthropy. 
Networking- you can literally reach out and meet with anyone to meet for coffee, etc. 

You can get involved in a lot of extracurriculars supported by the bank which is nice.
cons:
Like any big company- your management team can make your life great or miserable. Unfortunately, my experience was the latter:

-despite exceptional (exceeds/exceeds) peformance, minimal pay raises (1.8-2.1%) with no transparency on the compensation formula. 

-watching 50-year old managers have panic attacks over a slide deck about some non critical topic.

-always being promised a promotion to the next band level due to exceptional performance, but never following through despite being persistent 

- below average stock bonus and no ESPP

I’m sure there are plenty of managers who create a positive environment but after 5 years several of my peers have similar feelings.

There is always (always) a very urgent /emergency push to produce any deliverables , despite how menial the task. Everything is an emergency.

cons: From what callers expressed it seems BOA's reputation with its customers is terrible; So many customers have had negative experiences with the company and they end up taking it out on you over the phone. Bad attitudes, snarky comments etc. (typical customer service issues)You're not given the power to really solve issues and end up having to transfer customers to supervisors (which could take an hour because their busy with other calls, making customers more angry).

headline: Placed in Spanish speaking branch and couldn’t speak Spanish. Denied transfer.

cons: They don’t truly care about their associates. I was placed at a location where 95% of the clientele spoke Spanish and very little English. I was expected to run a cash drawer and meet referral goals under those circumstances. I asked to be transferred several times to a different branch and my manager ignored me. I was also told I couldn’t have a translator. I experienced reverse discrimination. I was one of two white associates in the entire branch.

Even after completing entire process they put candidature on hold suddenly.
HR don't even bother to reply and revert over the mails and calls, they are not even kind to inform that candidature is kept on hold for some reason.

They simply evaluate other candidates and keep all other selected employees on hold and don't even formally communicate.

DON'T EVER RELY ON BOA OFFER, they take their own sweet time and don't even bother about the candidates.
Epitome of unprofessionalism.

headline: Relationship Banker = Teller
pros: Good benefits. Seems like higher pay than other banks but relationship bankers are the lowest paid employees at the banks.
cons: I was hired for the relationship banker position and they leave out a huge part of the role in the job description and interview process. You’re a teller most of the time (possibly all of the time). This is because they are no longer hiring tellers. Relationship bankers are the lowest paid position at the banks. You get paid BofA’s minimum wage. There is nothing wrong with being a teller but that is simply not the experience and customer interaction that I was looking for. As a relationship banker working as a teller they expect you to ask probing questions and set up appointments. When you’re at the teller line and there is a line of people waiting that is unrealistic. I think that the title of the role and the description is a bait and switch tactic. They use the possibility of promotion to keep employees motivated but I saw very little signs of promotions at the two financial centers I worked at. Also, they hired me and trained me at one location but wouldn’t tell me what bank I would end up working at after training. They’re very inflexible about switching roles. You must be in your role for at least a year before they consider even transferring you to a different location. They promise that they try to place you near your house but they really don’t care. I also heard from others that they were moved to a new bank with no notice- just an email to show up at a different bank the next day. Everyone seemed unhappy.

Some projects and frameworks does not make sense to proceed or get accepted, and they move forward only because of politics. headline: Not a good place to work. Highly dismissive and disrespectful to all employees.
pros: Camaraderie between our fellow colleagues
cons:
Not a good place to work. 
Uncompetitive pay.
Inflexible, rigid and unnecessary work location.
No individual offices - cramped, crowded and noisy work area in a cube farm regardless of tenure, title or position.
Bonus structures no longer linked to performance - 100% discretionary which empowers middle management to prevent any dissent or collaborative environment.
Relentless propaganda to camouflage reality and threats of disciplinary and compensation consequences for any hint of dissent.
Management never seek employee input and ignore any suggestions or advice.
Management make promises and set expectations but rarely follow through and bristle when asked for updates.
Several of my colleagues have left in the last six months and are being replaced with less qualified, and less capable people due to other companies offering far superior remuneration, flexibility and work conditions.

headline: Eh - other places are better
pros: There are a lot of internal groups and causes. They do a lot for Charlotte and overall diversity. Neurodiversity.
cons: Most areas are organized and efficient but there is so much going on with reorgs it’s wasteful. They use Agile and Waterfall in such a custom manner that you need a Bank degree in order to manage change. You have little authority unless you’re a Band 4. It can be frustrating for her hires and many leave after six months in some cases. Other banks offer 6% 401k this bank only 5%. There is no clear direction in some areas which leads to little work getting done. They segregated Project Managers from Agile Teams so morale takes a huge hit. This is not the bank Hugh McColl ran. They offer no flex schedules or flex locations we are all back in an office which is disappointing compared to other banks.

headline: Terrible experience in the Credit Center as a Lending Officer
pros: Learning how to look up information in a policy that is 700 (seriously) pages
cons:
I was a Commercial Credit Lending Officer in the “CreditCenter” department for 3 years and had a horrendous experience.

The department has a lot of talented and hard working people but most LO’s in this department are overworked and miserable, mainly due to high turnover which strains the work capacity of all the remaining LOs. The department is a sweatshop, as everyone has to take on way too much work and struggles to keep up with their portfolios. Working efficiently in this department is very difficult as employees have to deal with convoluted procedures and primitive / glitchy computer systems. At my prior employer I won awards and was recognized as being in the top 5 producers out of 50 in my department but in this department I am continually being told I am not doing a good enough job on my unreasonable workload. 

Upper management, sitting in Chicago, should be ashamed and embarrassed by the horrible situation this department is in. Management tries to make improvements and changes, but the changes they make are just band aids. The department has been in such bad shape for so long that I don’t think management realizes how bad the situation actually is...

There are three kinds of people in the creditcenter department: New employees, those who are looking for a new job and those who have given their two week notice. Bank of America pays decently but they could have doubled my salary and I would not have stayed in the department. 
In the past three years during my employment at Bank of America I have developed a sleeping disorder, started therapy sessions, and have seen significant weight gain...I am now happy to have Bank of America in my rear view mirror.

headline: A good retirement home, but definitely a trap for any ambitious person
pros:
- Impossible to get fired - if you're junior, just come to work & you will likely be employed the next year. Biggest risk is breaching compliance e.g. not completing your training on time (that is VERY serious). Managers just need to clap like seals when senior managers talk & they are set. If they can write fancy emails and cc mgmt that is even better. 

-Pay is good relative to the amount of effort you put in (close to zero)

-Good entertainment perks e.g. Dinner budgets
cons:
- Most managers won't teach you anything. Mgmt's KPI is how well they can delegate work to subordinates. Most have 0 idea about the business they are running, but rely on competent subordinates to do the job. Most subordinates will eventually leave, except those who are trapped on 500K salaries but contribute very little. 

-Bonus is one of the lowest on the street. Unless you're the CEO making 23 million dollars & taking a private jet from Charlotte to Boston every week. Don't expect to be paid well (esp in Equities) & your bonus is not very well correlated to your output (which is intentionally kept very vague). 

-Feels more like a charity than a bank that cares about profits. I understand the importance of diversity/inclusion, but it is done a bit excessively here. E.g. Internal seminars that teach you how to interact with LGBT.....

- The bank actively disencourages innovation. Obviously, they don't put it like this, but try to suggest new ideas & it will likely die in layers of bureaucracy after your request is forwarded through three different continents. Most technology applications & popular websites are blocked, and most tech teams will either not respond or come back to you weeks later. It helps to have a boss who has sway in the bank & can help you get resources, so if you don't.... then too bad. 

-Onboarding clients is a pain. The amount of documents required by the team is often painful for clients, and clients who want to do business with us are often turned away for random reasons such as 'Lacking potential'. These decisions are often made by people in the team who can't tell the difference between alpha & beta.

-Everyone good is gone. There was once a time when there were still good people in the division. I define good as people who know clients well & have a good sense of the market. Those have mostly gone either to the buyside or moved to other houses. This means that the people you are left with cannot teach you anything that will make you useful to clients. 

There are so many more but these are specific to this bank and specific to a division and specific to a region.

headline: abandon hope, all ye who enter
pros:
Securities/markets side of the business are rewarded well.

If you are from Goldman Sachs, Bofa is a great place to retire.

If you are looking to be employed, and manage to negotiate a high salary, it is an ideal place to switch off from anything mentally taxing.
cons:
Middle management only care what their senior management think of them. staff considerations never seem to occur to them.

Administration seems to be the only goal. Generating money, creating ideas, or anything positive is negatively looked at, as middle management never want to rock the boat. It is a stale environment.

Flexibility is sneered at. Senior management have a view similar to that of cotton factories of the 18th century. They want to monitor employees regardless of what is actually being done and ensure that all are in the office all of the time. Middle management don't want to rock the boat so they nod and look to enforce out dated views.

headline: Large company, poor middle-managers
pros: Great benefits, health, dental, vision tuition reimbursement, 16 weeks of maternity/ paternity leave, sick days and ample vacation time varies with band level. BofA is well-known brand, established brand (versus a start-up). Several affinity/employee resource groups to get involved with. Finally replaced outdated leaders with new more promising leaders. Commitment to raise minimum pay to $21.
cons: Confusing, job descriptions. Middle management needs a complete overhaul and is filled with poor managers and their proteges that act and think the same way. Touts awards for "Diversity" yet company lacks ethnic and cultural diversity in Senior and Middle Management. Culture supports favoritism and mostly white men in executive roles and middle management. "You remind me of myself when I was younger" culture .....results in less hiring/promotion of People of Color and more hiring/promotion/mentorship of white men and women regardless of their background or experience. Zero transparency around the promotion process. External hires with no experience are paid more than "tenured" employees with direct experience. Company refuses to disclose pay/promotion/hiring stats to public. Public commitments made to address external social issues, but no changes are being made to address internal inequities in hiring, promotion and professional development.

headline: Save your mental health...
pros: Okay compensation and good benefits. High 401k matching. Learned and experienced a lot. Met a lot of great associates and great opportunity to be a peer mentor. Clients were nice for the most part.
cons: All politics. Unrealistic and outdated goals. Very high sales pressure. Have to do every single thing perfect, no room for mistakes for audits. Survey pressure. Micromanagement. Forcing us to force products and referrals on clients so numbers look good. No work/life balance with 6 day work weeks and hours changing all the time. Do 9/10 things right but the 1 wrong thing is harped on. Always short staffed. Reports on top of reports within reports. They say theres room to move around within the company, assuming you would be supported. I told my manager for months that I wasn't a sales person and would love help to move to a different department. I was told he would do the best he could but alas.

headline: Wrongfully terminated during pandemic
pros: Macro managed. Your in control of your own success. Management supported and respected each individuals chosen career path equally. For example, An individual that valued a work life balance was not treated or managed any different than the individual that valued working 70 hours a week to fast track a career path.
cons: Training was very scattered, unorganized and a majority of it was peer driven. I was forcefully placed on disability leave while incapacitated due to prolonged complications from COVID -19. It was very obvious that my termination was expedited due an unauthorized leave of absence that i wasn't aware was placed on. By the time i had recovered enough to try to understand the reality of the devi stating consequences it caused for my family, I called and was told no information could be given because i was no longer an employee and the three sentence termination letter stating that I took an unauthorized leave of absence that I never requested or initiated, and that i will also be considered not re-hire able should answer any questions I have. As soon as I can get back on my feet and somehow get a job in the industry i have been in for over 18 years, and fix my rent history and pay down my utility bills, I will be perusing legal counsel to have my termination investigated as a wrongful termination.

headline: Stay Away They Lead through Fear
pros: Decent Benefits for you and your family
cons:
Bank of America is the next Wells Fargo Lawsuit waiting to happen. Leaders call you at 8:00 at night harassing you to perform and verbally abuse you. If you open one IRA account they harass you as to why you didn't open 2 or 3 for the same customer. They attempt to motivate you through fear by docking pay of yourself and your team and do not reward going above the standard minimum.
Other than losing the authentic client interaction through the numerous repetitive disclosures and scripts you have to read, you're also encouraged to set bogus future appointments for customers and lie about how many client interactions you sit with in a day. Every year your bonus pay will be deducted and our team calculated individually we'd lose between a range of 19-21% of our annual pay for 2021. 2020 we lost 8%. 2019 we lost 5%. The metrics did not change.
Stay away from this company if you value feeling good about yourself.

headline: Mortgage Loan Servicing
pros: Great benefits including tuition reimbursement and lots of PTO
cons: This was a mortgage servicing position. The virtual training was awful after getting through the initial learning. It was very unorganized. The coaches were pretty rude. They would give incorrect or contradictory informationfrom previous information they'd given. I'd never experienced anything like it. They would patronize you for calling them out on the contradictions or misinformation or speak to you as if you weren't intelligent enough to see that they were talking down to you. Everyone in my training class saw it and a few of us complained but nothing really changed. A lot of time was wasted for trouble shooting or waiting for the coaches to get their calls together. Also there isn't any bonusing and their reason was because there were no sales. Coming from another financial institution we would bonus based on QA, Average Call Time, and our NPS scores. The bonuses would be tiered based on how well you performed.

headline: work life balance is horrible

cons: Management has undergone constant changes during covid. Different managers will have different expectations from you. They are constantly increasing their “expectations”/metrics with no increase of pay. Be prepared to cold call clients who you have never met in order to convince them to come into the banking center 98% will not pick up and the other 2 percent will to either pick up and curse at you or agree to the appointment and never show up even with a proper follow up. headline: My experience working at Bank of America
pros: BofA had very good benefits while I was there (not sure if that's still the case). They even offered tuition reimbursement, childcare reimbursement, and adoption assistance. They were a much better company to work for rather than as a customer.
cons: Very stingy with raises (offered.10¢ extra an hour as a promotion). Their reasoning was that they offered so many other benefits, however, at the time, I wasn't using any of them. Several times, my manager would change my timesheet until I called her out. Also, sales was a huge deal, which I did not enjoy.

headline: Think twice!!
pros: Great benefits like medical/dental plans & 401k incentives. The company has many different avenues for growth. However, it may not work in your favor if you are not on the same page as your manager. It seems to have a "I'll scratch your back if you scratch mine" environment.
cons: The sales goal pressure is out of this world if you work at a retail financial center. Management makes a huge difference. They don't seem to understand the importance of a work life balance and periodically stalk your social media. Since the pay isn't the best, don't consider getting another source of income that is not a conflict of interest as they will make you choose between the jobs you have.

headline: Great Compensation, but Quality Leadership is Completely MIA
pros: Being that I am part time and receive better benefits than a lot of full time positions out there, it is definitely very generous compensation. The small team I get to work with are sincerely wonderful and passionate people who work extremely hard every single day despite the lack of support from up top.
cons:
COVID has had a crippling impact on the company's culture, or at least in my center it has. They pander to the public in the media about how socially conscious they are now, but their lack of involvement in poor disenfranchised communities like mine make it clear that this is all a thinly veiled PR stunt with no substance to speak of. Upper management continues to move the goalposts with regards to their expectations for financial center employees, and they consistently fail to follow through on their word.

They routinely neglect the emotional well-being of their associates. Turnover and staff shortages are rampant with no end in sight. There is always a long hold to submit HR complaints because they are also understaffed and inundated with frustrated employees. 

Upper management seems to be willingly exploiting the dysfunction. They are completely unable and or unwilling to grasp the severity of the problems financial center staff face on a daily basis. Yet they attempt to micromanage every asinine detail of their associates' workday despite the fact they are essentially never physicslly present, opting instead to cower at home remotely while their most vulnerable staff are left to scramble together answers for leadership that refuses to accept critcism of any kind.

They want to wring their hands and deflect accountability because of the pandemic, but only in ways that suit them at the top. For regular employees who aren't given remote work options, too bad. This is why people have always felt since the beginning that "essential" is actually just code for "disposable."

headline: Csr
pros:
It improves company reputation.
Paired with genuine action, a CSR policy can serve to build or improve your business reputation. If it happened that your brand has had a negative backlash that led to losses, especially due to environmental issues, this policy would be a great solution to repair reputation damage and eventually restore profitability. In many cases, adopting CSR works as part of a business model, where consumers are often seen demonstrating more loyalty to a brand that is able to demonstrate commitment to environmental issues.
cons:
It can create shareholder resistance.
While some investors do seek to acquire stocks in companies that are socially responsible, most of them would make such an investment with the expectations of turning a profit. Also, while some companies have generated substantial profit from corporate social responsibility, others that adopted such a policy often prove as likely to lose money. With the spotty track record of CSR in demonstrating increases in profit, investors tend to resist attempts by company leaders to move their organizations in that direction.

headline: Your experience as an employee depends on your supervisor.
pros:
I found that your experience as an employee at Bank of America depends on your supervisor. If you have a supervisor who has management experience, is fair, does not have a chip on his/her shoulder, and is not pushing any agenda, then you'll have a good experience working here. 

Another pro is that Bank of America has a pretty good benefits package.
cons:
If you have a supervisor who does not know how to manage people or who has an agenda, or who doesn't understand or abide by generally accepted workplace norms (i.e. no talking about politics in the office, no racist or sexist jokes in the office) then you'll have a bad experience working here. 

There's no use going to upper-level management or to HR to report the inappropriate behavior, either. You'll either need to suck it up and put up with the racist, sexist, homophobic, and political comments, or you'll have to find another job.

headline: The best company
pros:
* The bar here is really low so its easy to outperform. Nobody else does anything useful.

* If you are let go from other banks for non performance you can end up here and become a MD/Director easily.

* You get talented people to do the work, then you take their projects and throw them under the bus and your MD will manage them out, because people who know what they are doing are a threat. Works well for everyone !

* The business basically collects rent in the worlds largest economy , so regardless of what state your projects are delivered in .. if they are at all ... it doesnt matter. The goal is to take as much money as possible from the annual technology budget. Whee..

* If you come from a rich London family you get promoted even if all your deliverables fail.

* You get to see what one extreme of "interesting" culture looks like !
cons: * If you are one of the people doing the work, sucks for you. Expect zero bonus. They will take your project, throw you under a bus and give you no bonus. This is of course a small price to pay for an up front seat to see how these people work. Like a precious visiting art collection .. this is REALLY special.. needs to be seen to be believed.

headline: Not a company you will grow with
pros: To the young ambitious career-oriented women out there, graduating from college, or those seeking a career change/path. This is a great resume builder because the BAML name is prestigious. Put in some time and leave -- this will not be the end all be all for you to achieve your career goals -- and the management/unbearable culture will belittle you into believing otherwise (i.e., you have capped and need to try harder to meet your current role). Your gut is not wrong, you are capable and should move on fast before you get stuck at the Applebee’s of financial firms. The amount of internal company/division specific programs they continuously create for you to “achieve accolades” are only so great within the firm. Just like being the best waiter at Applebee’s – memorizing that menu like the back of your hand and getting pins for your achievement -- that translates to nothing in the real world for you to build your career on. Ask the women with 20+ year tenures how their career track and salary have progressed. It says it all.
cons: the culture is archaic .

pros: This company really cares about its employees. They truly invest in them and make sure they know they are valued. They have so many options to customize your benefits and your job. I can’t sing their praises enough.
cons: In my specific department, there are managers that don’t know how to manage. They don’t do the work or understand that every person is different and therefor have to adjust your one on ones with that employee based on how they learn best. Some are lazy with research and don’t given true support. This is not all manager but I think there needs to be a refresher in appropriate management and enhance their communication skills.

headline: Healthcare Coverage
pros: Coverage is good. It even includes $20k coverage for adoption or fertility benefits.
cons:
It is not adjusted to cost of living but is based on compensation < and > $100K. If you are in the upper bracket, premium has risen considerably since Obamacare passed. The rise seems to compensate/ offset the increase cost for the lower bracket.

While theoretically a good plan, in reality, it hurts employees in the high cost of living areas like NYC, SF Bay area. $100K compensation is barely middle class entrance.

headline: Stability, but underpaid, under appreciated, and frustrating
author_position: Assistant Vice President Production Services Lead
pros: At BofA you have stability. Unless you go out of your way to cause issues and are hostile, it is nearly impossible to be fired. Incompetency is tolerated, mediocrity is rewarded, if you stay long enough you have built-in guaranteed raises every year.
cons: Talent is under appreciated and your time is not valued. Putting in long hours and working through lunches and breaks is expected with no compensation in return. The "bonuses" are a joke, people in charge have fallen upwards because of tenure, and you are paid some of the lowest wages in the industry. Mobility is stagnant even though the company puts on a show to advocate for your career advancement. If you are looking to blend in, this is the company for you. If you are looking to stand out, find somewhere else.

headline: Great Place to Work at any Career Level
pros: CEO and company care about their associates, customers, and clients. Yes, it is a bank and we always want or expect more than what we have at hand, but offices, training, equipment, benefits package, staff, and customers are decent people. Salaries are very negotiable, thus represent yourself honestly and directly during your interview and I suggest no more than two interviews per position. If they want you they will make a quick offer because after all, you are looking for a new position/work/career.
cons: Some teams have improperly trained associates/management teams which could create extended working hours. Some positions have lower pay than other banks, therefore do your research.

headline: D&I is all lip service
pros: Solid non-management teammates, decent benefits
cons:
White men fail up. Women and POC expected to pick up the slack constantly. If you are the only woman in the meeting (still very likely), you will be expected to take notes, and coordinate any follow ups. 
You may have to train your manager to respect boundaries. Many of them think salary = 24/7 on-call.
Lots of effort in D&I programs but no actual change or progress. EXTREMELY ABLEIST policies, especially regarding remote work. In theory, accommodation is available and easy to request. In practice, there are tons of roadblocks and managers actively discourage employees from requesting them.
Facilities are a MESS and unless you work for Merrill, good luck getting any issues fixed.

headline: RTO as Covid Numbers Continue to Increase?
pros: My team is filled with very knowledgeable people.
cons: BM and his executive level cohorts seem to be putting their own interests ahead of the best interest of their employees. Originally everyone was to return to the office 9/9, several weeks ago without any formal announcement they changed that to vaccinated employees that have registered their vaccinations with the Bank. If you are willing to risk your life to go back to work for a management team that doesn't care about your well-being, that is your choice. With the rising Covid numbers, they should not be forcing anyone to return to office at this time.
