headline: Job isn't as customer focused as you would think it would/should be.
pros: Benefits are great, Pay is good and will be increasing, Diversity is top notch, Inclusion, most branches have a Community based concentration.
cons:
Relationship Banker requires you to do teller duties that aren't clearly stated in job description. 
If micromanagement isn't a good fit for you steer away from this job.
Job promotion is contingent upon which employee the manager and regional manager favor the most.
Unclear on what the requirements are to become branch manager, many that are in these positions aren't the most people friendly and don't have the best interpersonal skills needed to be a respected branch manager.
The tellers are being pressured into becoming a relationship banker to coincide with the new direction the company is headed potentially forcing many qualified employees to seek new employment or early retirement.
The work life balance leaves you tired, stressed and working 6 days out of the week which makes it hard to plan for any family events or personal time. 
Schedule requests are required for the year in advance (may be branch manager preference) which is the most unrealistic request. 
I can continue with more "Cons" but i'd rather not spend my sunday

headline: Changes are not always a good thing

Good compensation

Low rates

cons:
Too many employees in the mortgage dept that have no accountability for time lines and initiatives to getting things done. Hire more quality people.
Too many meaningless tasks that occupy way too much time which is not acceptable in a commission/bonus heavy structure
Broken appraisal system that requires us to follow up and call two to three times a day in order to get appraisal back a day before the close of escrow
Quarterly compensation that is paid out TWO MONTHS after the quarter ends.
Goals are completely random and set every single quarter with no clear formula of how the number was determined

headline: Steady hours, poor training
pros:
-Knowing your hours is nice
-Good health and PTO benefits
cons:
-You don't really get trained, you will be thrown out to the floor expected to take clients and figure out how to do it as you go, which clients notice and give you a hard time for. Your manager may explain something to you one time and then get angry at you months later for missing it, and will try to cover themselves by saying they went over it with you many times.
-COLD CALLS!!! You are expected to do "proactive outreach" calls, which are just cold calls to the clients in your area with a very awkward script with no real purpose. They do not disclose this in detail at all during the hiring process. So if you don't want cold calling being a big part of your life, stay away.
-Hourly pay with no incentives, they will ask you to reach goals with no prospect of making a bonus for exceeding them
-Depending on your manager, you may be left to fend for yourself, even with angry clients. Some managers show no interest in helping you diffuse a situation, leaving you feel like you're on an island during a difficult situation.
-No flexibility. Your schedule belongs to the bank. They will deny you PTO months out and then ask you to work even when you do get approved.

headline: Sharks Wanted
pros: bank holidays off. some of the people were cool. we hated the job but got along very well.
cons: Bank of America has horrible leadership. There are a ton of boss' but no leaders. No one that can build relationships with their teams and work with a group of people towards a common goal. "Vice Presidents" are a dime a dozen. Throw a check register and you'll hit a Vice President. There are so many. VP of what? Scamming people?? They only care about money. Their goals prove it. They take the human element out of a "sit" and a customer becomes another number to try to get as many products as possible with even if they already have it. Its all hidden behind the guise of "doing what's best for the member". Give them an additional credit card or checking account regardless if they need one. If you have that kind of shark-like quality to you, then look no further than this place. You will get praises from the top down and a bonus.

headline: repeat the same day every day
pros: You do not have to be outstanding to do anything here. If you do what you're told, don't try to stand out, you can coast and get a steady paycheck. This is the job you hold if you're fine doing the same thing every day and a 3% pay rise is fine for you.
cons: 1) Ambition is not rewarded. 2) If you take a day off everything goes wrong because no one else will know how to do what you do. Your work life balance will be ruined. 3) If you go back to school expect management to assume you want to quit. The company boasts they want to change things and improve processes. What they really mean is make easier to use spreadsheets that almost automate what you do, or can automate you out. I "upskilled" myself while there and never got any offers to move up despite the company forcing us to attend meetings that explain how upskilling will help us move up in the company. They have training modules that give you worthless certifications at the end. The certifications have fancy titles. No one ever noticed or cared. The only person who did seem to notice was my immediate manager who felt if I had so much time to complete training modules then it means I don't have enough work to do. Also, you're told to do upskilling training modules in your free time but discouraged from doing it during work hours. But you're not allowed to do the modules from home. The company says one thing but does the other. And expect to be lied to by managers if you ask for a raise or want to apply to a different team. I was always able to hear my manager through the door and I know how they speak to each other. There's still some systemic racism. I didn't want to believe it at first but its there. Sexism is very obvious.

headline: Worst experience in 18 yr career. Beware!
pros: Bank of America has name recognition, great benefits and great technology . Diversity in hiring people from many ethnicities.
cons: 99% of all loan officers quit the firm over the last 10 months when they took away our monthly commissions and replaced it with quarterly bonuses. They fired most of the support team which the responsibility of those roles fell upon the loan officer. They retooled the position and now loan officers are now loan officers and relation managers opening checking accounts, credit cards,and auto loans. The bonuses for this type of work reduces the pay of the loan officer by 90%. This is why they quit. I'm in temporary disabilty however I will be fine soon. The most senior level loan officers who've worked there for years have all quit. Now the underwriters are quitting and its incredible that loans are even closing. My guess is they will be permanently shutting down the division or making the position centralized. Oh and they overwork everyone and trim their pay every year. This business model of screwing their faithful employees will catch up to them one day.

headline: Stifling work environment
pros:
Reasonable benefits including government holidays.
Stable company will probably be around a long while.
cons:
Office politics are very heavy here.
The money to be made is at the top echelons--most of the top execs are raking in large annual increases while most workers are getting a tiny percent (if anything). Even strong-performers get only small annual increases which are nearly the same as under-performers. Increases are usually less than inflation.
The work is less satisfying here because much time is spent on meeting the requirements of regulators and auditors rather than actually doing IT work.
Once in a position, if you do a good job in that position, it is virtually impossible to move to another position. Moving to a new position is very much top-down in this organization--the management decides what you should be doing and they will move you into that role with little or no input from you.
Of all the jobs I have worked, the stress level here is higher than anywhere else.

headline: Depends On Your Manager
pros: The program's coordinators/managers are extremely helpful and attentive to participants' individual needs. When I had an issue with my manager, my program manager swiftly took action and served as a middle-man to help the situation. Even with everyone being remote, they truly did their best to foster a sense of community and promote networking by organizing events for the TAP class.
cons: I wasn't really assigned a role, and instead was just given tasks to do on a daily basis, creating a sense of being an intern. However, other TAP participants very much enjoyed their roles that they were actually assigned to, and truly assimilated into their teams.

headline: Good Benefits, good people, unrealistic metrics
pros:
The benefits are great. If a loved one dies you get 20 days of bereavement compared
To the 5 days you would get elsewhere. Vacation package is standard but maternity/paternity leave is excellent. Childcare reimbursement is great and so we’re my coworkers. Most of them I’m still friends with. Immediate managers mostly do the best they can and are amazing people.
cons:
Building was old and in need of updates. Call center environment was extremely micro managed and metrics were unrealistic. It requires you to be on one hundred all day long with a 30 minute lunch break. Working at that frantic level with back to calls is unsustainable mentally and takes a toll. I developed high blood pressure, I gained weight from stress eating , it exasperated my PTSD by constantly triggering adrenaline responses. As a result it was difficult to sleep and created a feeling of dread every morning before work and every Sunday thinking about the week ahead. I’m a single mom so when I got home I didn't have the energy I needed to take care of home. You can’t schedule vacation when you want. It’s often denied. If you are new and want your kid’s birthday off and a senior person wants the same day, they would get it. All of that adds to the stress level. Plus, I was struggling financially off of 55k as a single parent with 2 kids. I worked hard and sacrificed to get my s7, and s66 licensing.

It. is very hard to move out of the call center as every one wants to leave so there may be 5 openings with 100 applicants. So it’s extremely easy to get hired but very difficult to get promoted. The pay is sub standard. Upper management (2-3 levels up) can be prejudiced and resentful. Location does matter. At my site, there were very little opportunities to move up and those who did move up were often the ones drinking and partying with Managemet on Friday nights. I’ve seen my black high performing colleagues (top 3) get passed over for promotions for very trivial reasons. I wasn’t using my talents. I left for a competitor and was hired on the spot for 40k more plus bonus and for a higher position in the company. They were able to see my worth and I’m happy now and thriving. Thirty pounds came right off within 6 months. As far as Diversity and inclusion: lots of people of color at the bottom and gets pale as you move up the pyramid.

pros: Especially during the pandemic, Bank of America has really stepped it up in terms of taking care of us associates. Working in consumer banking can be tough at the best of times, but especially so while we're dealing with a global catastrophe, but I really felt looked after as an individual and as an employee. During non-pandemic times, at least within my team I always feel valued and look forward to the challenges that the day will bring me, and my performance never goes unrecognized.
cons: upwards movement or to other lines of business from consumer outside of consumer is sometimes prohibitively difficult. Leadership who does not come from banking background can sometimes feel unsupportive because they don't know how things work down at the ground level.

headline: Great Pay, Benefits, but Location Matters
pros: The pay sets the bar for retail banking in this role. The benefits are incredible. The company provides great resources for learning - though you will have to fight for the time to use them. Excellent employee networks that can allow you to network inside the company.
cons: Location matters, your manager matters. Good managers will support their direct reports, elevate them and help them succeed. Others may be focused only on their own success - if you find yourself with one of these managers, you end up having to look for an opportunity to transfer. Being at a strong performing location will also push your career forward, whereas being at a slow location could hinder your advancement.

headline: Great benefits, poor employee care
pros: Great healthcare benefits and work perks. 2 weeks paid vacation and 40 hours of sick time annually
cons: Financial centers are short staffed and centers are run to the ground. The company cares about how they look in front of the media, not what employees actually think. They will let a center run on 2 employees and knowingly allow a manager to work 6 days a week because he doesn’t get paid overtime. Employees are just a number. The bank is consolidating employees and trying to see how little employees they need to run a center. Training and rules differ from center to center, resulting in inconsistent client experience and no way to build credibility with clients who have already had bad experiences at multiple other centers.

cons: The cons are the normal you would expect in any call center. Team leaders are stressed out, especially during the pandemic. Plus whenever there is movement of employees, either by transfer, retirement or whatever, it always causes stress and delays. Then of course the very nature of a call center guarantees there will be issues and lots of them with upset customers.

headline: Overall Good Company
pros: Global company with offices throughout US and international. Opportunities (on occasion) to transfer to new location as needed. Overall good benefits (health, 401K, etc). A lot of benefits cater to the younger employees (family related benefits). Long term disability is offered, decent vacation and sick time (but not allowed to carry over in normal times). I believe Brian Moyihan continues to think of his people and his company and chooses to make the right decisions.
cons: Most of the Bank mgmt still believes in working from the office instead of remotely. It was proven with Covid that people could be very efficient and productive working remotely if they choose too. Management mentality is "butts in seats" which is not logical. Obviously certain roles require being in an office (ie branch, people in data centers etc) - but the vast majority should be ABLE to work from home if they choose and not be chastised for it. Eliminated pension plan contributions (much like other companies) - but grandfathered in those who had them earlier. Dental and vision plans need to be enhanced -- they are pretty much the same of what's been offered for over 20 years. Especially with Covid -most people are working longer and more stressful work (and home) lives - but there is always some sense of urgency by mgmt which demands impact on personal life.

headline: Stable Company/ Lots of Demands

headline: They No Longer Have MLOs

BoA will have a very difficult time hiring experienced MLOs ever again if this current experiment doesn’t work for them.

headline: Company itself is AMAZING, just please try to avoid roles in Financial Centers.
pros: Great company to work for especially right out of college. Fantastic people in HR.
cons:
Excessive micromanaging in the management of the Financial Center I worked in. There is definitely some people who bring down the average quality of people who work in Consumer Banking. I felt like I was being watched with every breath I took, which eventually took a toll on my mental health. 

It also didn't help that as an employee of Asian and Pacific Islander descent, I felt like I was in constant danger with the whole Covid situation. It was absolutely horrifying working in an office where the leader was not only ignorant, but also showed complete disregard to the recent AAPI hate.

headline: Not for you if you aren’t into sales!!!
pros: Great experience of you are in financing
cons:
Too much of a sales job
Managers get in trouble for not meeting their Mark so the tellers take all the blame.
They want you to bug the customers.
If you can’t get any accounts open, credit cards, loans, refinancing, they will basically tell you you’ll be fired if you any meet a certain sales mark daily. 
If you aren’t into sales or good at sales, starting at a bank will not be for you.

headline: Great program, surprisingly amazing environment.
pros: Some of the brightest individuals you will ever work with who are also humble and friendly. I was expecting a cutthroat environment where people will jump over one another to move up. That is not the case from what I have seen. Despite being a huge company, the people at my branch are very friendly and supportive. You have many resources to help you succeed.
cons:
No vacation time. You can use your sick time when needed, but it's hard to plan a trip and get "sick" that weekend. 
If you do not meet the department's quotas, you are gone. There is no chance for you to move to another department even if you just graduated from an MBA program and qualify for other roles. I brought this up to management in charge of national training and they made it clear that you would be out of the company.

Part timers share the same benefits as full timers

Their computers and equipment are old and outdated and tend to stop working all the time

headline: Overall a good place to work.
pros: Great benefits, inclusive culture, career advancement, the company cares about their employees, overall I had good managers and cool co-workers.
cons: High stress, at times it can be difficult to get the days off you want, and the desired shift you want. I was transferred out of an old dept. to a new one (I had no choice) that I did not want to be part of due to high stress. I had to wait basically a year before I could post out in which I was initially told I had to wait only 6 months. When I applied for a new position after 6 months, the recruiter advised I had to wait a full 12 months. That was not what I was told by management, at times there is a lack of CLEAR communication and miscommunication from management to employees.

headline: Best Company I’ve ever worked for
pros: I love being able to help others with their finances and life goals. You have to plan on how to execute your monthly and quarterly goals if you want to be successful at meeting or exceeding those numbers. But once you do, you can receive a $1,500 bonus or plenty more on a quarterly basis. Great benefits such as paid holidays off, 16-24week maternity leave, growth opportunities, tuition reimbursements, 3 weeks vacation a year and plenty of sick time, great health care, 401k matching up to 5%, and just several others.
cons: I came in with a lot of education on my finances and have learn what I teach my clients from my own life experiences. Wish there was more in depth training to make sure everyone was on the same page with what they teach clients. Your manager you have andbteam will make all the difference in the world on whether you love working their or not. I’ve had some teams I worked with that made me want to leave the bank and others I worked with that make me feel so blessed to have my job. Keep yourself educated and on track for promotional opportunities no one will do it for you.

headline: Horrible. Simply put. Horrible

Work from home if that's even a benefit anymore?

Position is good for someone literally so new to banking and know nothing. They promote "SBCs" that are clueless but follow their toxic regimen.

I got recurrent panic attacks

Disrespect

MICROMANAGEMENT

They took the small business bankers to hourly.

Salaries are weak

headline: Good for Entry Level, Good for Retirement, Bad for everything else
pros:
Big company, standard wall street benefits including 15 days Vacation and average medical plans. 401k 5% match and the usual standards
- Great for a fresh college grad with no credentials, down on their luck and rejected from top tier banks like JP, MS, or GS. Fill up that empty resume with one or two years of work before applying to one of the many better banks.
- Great for middle- aged employees with families to care for that aren't looking for career growth, and just want to clock their 9-5ers and collect basic paychecks. Can just coast towards retirement without doing much work and having much stress
cons:
- In Equities technology, you get some really garbage projects, doing data warehousing or OATS compliance work which contributes nothing to career growth and isn't quite marketable to future employers. 
- 1% to 5% yearly bonuses in a good year. 0% bonuses otherwise
- No base adjustments in salary unless you transfer jobs
- Discrimination from the business side. The business side, strats traders, etc, take all the bonuses and laugh in the face of their Technology teams. Technology folks get no respect and are treated like 4th class citizens in the bank, including being moved out of the main corporate building into a rental office space. Technology is a cost center and receives the lowest budget and worst reputation.
- Turnover among young people (aged ,<25) is very high, up to 80% last year. Six months after I left, a few applications nearly folded (or merged) because all their young employees also left.

headline: No Work/Life Balance
pros: Health Insurance and decent pay.
cons:
You sell people things they dont need for a whole ladder scheme for your personal bonus.
Management has some of the most questionable practices I've seen (I was working for WF in 2016/17!) and this is worse. Reporting it doesnt nothing unless its from a Client. 
People are miserable all the time and understaffed so everyone works insane hours and if you dont "Your not a team player." 
The tellers are treated like animals and the bankers like cash cows that have to "earn you check" so downtime of anykind is punished with your vacations not approved or management will tell the Tellers which banker to set the appointments with depending on who she liked that week. Overall its horrible and glad I got out before the pandemic was worse.

headline: Poor management
pros: Good benefits like child care reimbursement that will cover a portion of your child care expenses. 401k, medical, dental, vision, and legal. Tuition reimbursement. Shopping discounts. Associates have the same account benefits as a preferred rewards Platinum customer
cons: Poor management. Demanding schedules working 6 days a week. Constant last min changes to the schedule that are difficult to manage if you are a parent. Managers constantly give associates a difficult time about taking their annual vacation time. At the end of the current year you must schedule all your vacation time in advance for the following year. Forget trying to call out sick! Have a day off? They will insist you come in to help. Wanna take a personal day? You have to schedule it in advance with your manager when you schedule vacation time. They will ask you for specific details about what you want to do on your personal time before they consider approving it. Your personal cellphone is treated like a 24hr work phone. You will get work related messages at all hours. All the banking centers operate this way. This isn't an isolated incident to one particular center.

headline: Workplace drama, management that doesn't care about strategic solutions, hell for junior level employees
author_position: Assistant Vice President In Equities Derivatives IT
pros: Good teams, strong developers, knowledgeable business, potential for interesting work and internal mobility looked good (although I never moved, I saw many people moving internally and enjoying their new roles)
cons: Terrible frequently changing management lead to confused goals and money wasted on scrapped projects; management promotes bad workplace culture and doesn't care about the employees; HR and managers turn a blind eye to inappropriate behaviour in the office (affair between manager and direct report, teammates asking me inappropriate personal questions of a sexual nature in the office, the list goes on. Don't bother going to your manager or HR, they will literally tell you "I'm tired" because they are too worried about their own agenda to protect junior female employees. People would move to new roles within the company and leave behind major problematic projects and barely finished work for junior level employees with the advice "go figure it out";

headline: Best Company to work for
pros: When the pandemic started, Bank of America really showed how much they cared about their employees and took care of us... Giving us great benefits and great relief options, not firing us, giving us the option of working from home without any pay decrease while providing work equipment for us. We still got our bonuses from what we got on average without having any goals... They wanted to make sure our income stayed the same and we wouldn't struggle during covid. I am super grateful to be working for this company, and now I see it very clearly since the pandemic started. When things go bad, people's true colors came out, and I am so happy to be apart of this company.
cons: Lots of politics involved, but that's with every company.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Cooperative work culture and good camaraderie.
Competitive products and services but main strength is that the business is very client-centric. We put a lot of thought into how to best solve our clients' needs.
cons:
This is largely down to individual manager style but the office can be a bit political at times, as a lot of competitive people are vying for visibility.
Biggest con for me is not unique to BofA but I find that it goes against our otherwise team-based culture: The habit of performing a staff cull twice a year. I have seen several very capable colleagues made redundant over the years, and I find that we could do more to find new roles for people to continue within the organisation when a particular career step does not work.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Bank of America may be one of the best places to launch your career in banking. If you work hard you're able to form great relationships with co-workers, managers, and clients. You also get to learn a lot of things outside of the scope of your current role to prepare you for the future as long as you ask for the responsibility.
cons: Some of the biggest cons are more so the geographic limitations of the bank in Arkansas, if you want to move up, you'll have to move to a different geographic area. Due to the small presence in Arkansas, you deal with a lot of upset customers that want banking services but are driving long distances for one-on-one discussions. The small presence also means that as a banker, you are often one of no more than 10 servicing customers in a large population area.

headline: Good company to start in
pros:
Benefits-
Health, Dental, Vision, paid time off, paid sick time, tuition reimbursement, inclement weather pay, matching 401k.

If you like constant sales goals and helping clients who may not understand the financial world it might work for you. You can move up in the industry but the sales goals increase with every promotion.
cons:
Stress-
Everyone I knew who worked here was constantly stressed out. You have to do more than your share of work most of the time. Long lines, out the door during peak days. Very little help, especially during the pandemic. I would do anywhere from 100-250 transactions per day. Had to verify every single transaction at the end of the day, count my teller box and that of the vault. Do all the reports and most of the closing and opening procedures. If we were short staffed I had to count other tellers boxes as well. The center I worked at had very challenging clients. We would receive threats and complaints on a semi daily basis. They installed over head cameras to look at everything you do. Which is fine, but it piles on the stress knowing they're watching every mistake you make from a remote location. On top of stress from the clients, the low staffing, you have to promote sales goals for the personal bankers. It pays well but it is very demanding.

headline: Good Pay and Benefits
pros: Benefits were wonderful! The time off; sick and vacation is also very good! I started off with 15 days vacation and 10 sick days, the pay is pretty decent , they also offered monthly incentives for the majority of the time I was with the company, you’ll also get points for performance which you can use towards items or gift cards(I definitely took advantage of this and got a few with $100 gift cards!). You’ll also meet some pretty awesome fellow peers and another major pro I am thankful for is the experience I obtained on my resume.
cons: Argumentative callers, high stress back to back calls and very high call volumes. You’re  not allowed to go into ACW or sign off for a quick breather unless it’s one of your breaks or lunch- this can make you feel burnt out quickly, especially on those days where all you’ve had are very upset clients projecting their anger about policies towards the messenger(you), and heavy micromanagement when it comes to your AHT & offering self service to clients.

headline: Solid but depressing
pros: Good training and interaction with other employees. Exactly 15 minute breaks and 30 minute lunch feels short but gets you out on time at the end of the day. There is no room to play around, you go in, do what you are supposed to do, and leave. Which is a good thing. All your communications are heavily monitored and time tracked. Some volunteer opportunities.
cons: You can feel like a robot on the job, depending on your manager your life can be really miserable. I met some good people there and overall you're getting solid pay at a stable company with the opportunity for advancement. But being on a headset with angry people and trying to help them on a slow, outdated system really wears on you over time. If you can learn to not get stressed out by others, learn the system and learn how to talk to people, you will do decently here. But this is the worst job I've ever had. Time moves very slowly and you feel chained to your desk in a cubicle. If you don't have other things going on in your life you will be really depressed working here.

headline: Lots of Pros, Lots of Cons
author_position: Vice President Credit Risk Analyst II
pros: The pay is very competitive and there is a lot of opportunity to get involved in various aspects of credit risk. So the opportunity is there for the taking. The bank also supports career mobility both horizontally and vertically and has a great risk management principals.
cons: This relates primarily to my perception of the culture, but in general everyone's experiences will probably have a lot of various. But to focus on trends - not a lot of collaboration - work as well as compensation tends to be divided and the company rank orders performance based on executives tiering system. Most of the decision-making and information sharing occurs at the senior leadership level, so although there's lots of opportunities to learn and it's difficult for it to translate into a clear understanding of what to prioritize and how to make a meaningful contribution. Higher job titles or other groups may view this in a different way.

headline: Great Benefits, Poor Corporate Management
pros: They pay for your school, have great national min. wage policy, great reimbursement options, and they generally offer many other benefits to employees. Holidays are frequent as well.
cons: They stretch their staff as far as possible, avoiding hiring like the plague. Newly renovated lobbies contain archaic systems that 'meet expectations' but leave employees frustrated with frequent malfunctions and outdated systems. Sales pressure is huge, as with all banks and most for-profit companies I'm sure, but managers and bankers get the worst while Tellers are told to upsell upsell upsell. Great for a sales job, bad for someone looking for a more social role. Chronically understaffed branches and pedantic redundancies in a variety of branch operation procedures.

headline: New culture around controls and governance does not always align with Growth
pros:
- Great benefits for maternity and paternity
- Good health benefits for low wage employees
- Great support and benefits for employees with families.
- A company that is truly making changes to ensure every employee is treated equally.
- A culture of doing the right thing that ties into reducing regulatory, financial and reputational risk.
cons:
- Risk and control culture makes getting things done a hard endeavor.
- Emphasis on cost cutting due to the reasons mentioned below.
- Disconnect between the taking points from senior management and the ground realities in terms of compensation and ratings.

Bank of America is a very very very large bank with more employees than its competitors with larger market value and balance sheets. The companies culture has gone through a drastic change with emphasis on simplification, reducing risks, adding more controls and as a result a shrinking company. This is probably good news for many of its core customers and its shareholders but as an employee its a mixed bag given many of its competitors and Fintech can offer very exciting opportunities rewarding higher risk taking in terms of innovation in terms o technology. The control and risk averse culture means that BOA would shy away from pioneering any drastic change or a new venture looking at its competitors to take the pioneering risk in terms of new products, technology etc.

headline: Non-progressive company that hides bullying and racism
pros: I was able to learn key job functions that I could apply to a new role somewhere outside of the company. I gained experience that I would have not otherwise had.
cons: I had to take a personal leave due to extreme ptsd, I was texted by an employee harassing me for taking a leave. HR did nothing. I returned from leave to be demoted and had never been punished for any lack in work. I was in the process of suing but ended up getting a better job somewhere else. A friend of mine on the same team was also a victim of racist comments. Bank of America hr again did nothing.

headline: Basically a teller
pros: Good time off benefits, pay isn’t that bad either if you live in a small city.
cons:
Relationship banker is basically a teller. I started off as a relationship banker and after people slowly left instead of hiring a new teller simply made me the full time teller. 

If you have a college degree don’t bother. 

You’re basically a floater, don’t let the title fool you, it’s very very likely you’ll end up doing mostly teller work. Which is a great opportunity but not if you went to college and graduated with a useful degree and high GPA trust me.

headline: If I could truly give zero stars I would.
pros: The pro's would be the pay. Considering the minimum wage here in Delaware, Bank of America pays pretty well.
cons:
The work load is terrible. There is always something new being added on to your already long list of task. Management pushes out a few slides for you to read, then wants to label you an expert. The lack of support from management is terrible. Management brushes you off when you have questions, they try to avoid you during crucial times. If you like feeling alone, and not supported BOA is for you !
The work load, and work environment may cause a huge strain on your health, physically , and mentally. I would not recommend BOA to anyone.
During these tough times of a pandemic , incentives were cut. As we were advised we were "abusing" incentives (although we work extremely hard for them) , also yearly bonuses were cut. When we asked management , we were advised there would be no bonus " Considering all that was done for us this year" As if us being allowed to work from home was some sort of privilege. 
Everyday you are shown management does not care about you, only what you can do for them ( Take calls), and that customers are way more important to them than their own employees. Management can be extremely condescending, and flat out disrespectful, not only to you , but to customers at times, as well . 
Truly I would not recommend BOA to anyone, since working here I have experienced several health issues that are work related, and have not been supported at all. 
I suppose there is room to move around within the Bank, and traveling to several different departments. However that is assuming you will be supported. I told my manager that I wanted to branch off to a different department, and was told" she doesn't like to see good employees leave, she'll look into trying to give me a good review" essentially trying to sabotage my career within the bank.

headline: Great 1st or 2nd job
pros: Made friends with many coworkers. Provided tuition reimbursement while i went to community college. Taught me a great deal about personal finance from both the job itself, to speaking with customers everyday (especially the regulars who love to share knowledge). Overall a good experience.
cons:
certain managers would create pressure to present credit products to meet sales goals, which helped me understand the sales process and also understand that some choose to ignore their ethical bounds. My role was to create initial interest and for the personal bankers to close. Many if not most of the PB's I worked with were awesome but there are always a few bad apples ethically.

Also was frowned upon to take sick days. In WA it was fast paced on the teller side for busy locations yet they would understaff the tellers with the goal of pushing people towards mobile and the ATM

headline: Reasonably good place to work, but lots of manual processes
pros: Decent culture, people are generally helpful, and pockets of senior management are quite competent.
cons: A ton of manual processes, duplicative routines, and antiquated systems. While executive management seem to be chosen for leadership and results, some of the mid-level folk appear to be promoted more on loyalty and institutional knowledge instead of innovation and excellence. Though colleagues are pretty friendly, the company as a whole feels overly bureaucratic and conservative, which isn't conducive to ideas and creativity. Also the technology tends to be slow and consistently buggy, which can be a big drain on productivity and morale.

cons: At Home Equity, unit managers place favoritism on promotions, team leads need more leadership qualities; little room to really grow into other units; unit was mainly focused on filtering associates into Home Service Specialists. headline: The management hierarchy system, allows for favoritism, and a bulling playing ground
pros: salary, canteen, you cant hear a pin drop
cons:
Interview process took 5 months with 4 interviews and background checks.
Interview and HR process is a mix of outsourced companies that are offsite, the manager of the team or a different team will conduct the interview with team leads who pick there preferences as there your responsibility.
Interview process was made up of a fabrication of what they want the company to appear on the outside to be, buy telling you numbers of what they spend on good causes, and the minority's they support, truthfully they advertise as diverse but yet all higher management are old white men.
very unfriendly, toxic atmosphere, a bully's dreamland
Day one of the job after the previous 5 months HR advised me to let them know if I was going to leave as people seem to disappear around here often.,which I grew to find out was true.

headline: Good if you’re in corporate, retail banking is the worst.
pros: Good pay, good benefits, willing to bring people in from other customer service/sales jobs who can get better financial service positions after this one.
cons: Metrics were AWFUL and neither of the two RBs we had ever hit their target and funded their bonus. Instead of looking to see why no one in the branch funded their bonus they just pushed us harder. Micromanagement runs rampant. The pay is not worth it for the RB position. They do not follow through on promises. I also was switched from my set branch to another branch twice as far away in the last week of my training, which was 2 months, so they waited until the end to throw that on me.

headline: Caution
pros:
- Decent pay
- decent bonuses
cons: Awful place to work. You are basically a car salesman but for a bank. The Albany, NY area has notoriously bad leadership from top to bottom (ask any current or former employee). Regional supervisor guy thinks he’s The Godfather of the banking industry and carries himself in an painfully corny manner and everyone else needs to suffer when he’s around. You literally see grown women and men have panic attacks when bosses plan to show up, it’s THAT toxic. You’re also an hourly employee so whatever hours you miss- you MISS. And you also have to make up for those hours with double calls/emails. Plan to call and email 100 people a week, that is no exaggeration. Over and over.

headline: High pressure work environment
pros: Good training, good co-workers. The overall culture is optimistic. Market leaders care about front-line employees but have limited resources to help them.
cons:
High sales pressure, too many unclear internal regulations, no work-life balance, low wages, and basic benefits.
One thing that always threw me off was their customer satisfaction survey. Clients were unhappy with products, long wait times, and many other reasons that were not under bank employees' control. So no matter how hard we worked to help a client when they received a survey, they would give us a bad rating. Then, top management would blame the branch employees and deduct our bounces as punishment. I believe that was an extremely unfair business practice. Bank employees are never appreciated and most of them don't earn enough to live a decent life in the bay area.

headline: I have been with the bank for many many years to be able to write this
pros: great company for avg performer and especially for retirement. Great on paper culture and values and some are good in reality as well.
cons: not recommended for people seeking career or salary growth unless you're lucky to be in a specific team (odds are very very low). your increment, growth is directly proportionate to how strong your boss weigh among his peers and that's regardless of performance. people who work very hard, stretching & sacrificing a lot are often ignored and people who are slicker are often in good books.

headline: They want machines, don't treat you like humans
pros: Vacation time, health insurance, 401K
cons: Exploit tellers, no respect for personal life. I would be texted and called on days off because people at the branch didn't know what to do. They would make you feel bad about being sick or taking time off. Only one teller at a window so not able to use bathroom. Very stressful. Also, being promoted is based on who you know, not your metrics. I was annual top performer interested in relationship banker position, and would get told, I needed to increase my referral numbers, even though I was #1 in the market and exceeded 8% on a regular basis. Just awful culture.

headline: Great culture and good work/life balance

headline: Career growth
pros: Medical and internal Benefits as well as banking perks
cons: Development programs for career growth

headline: Take care of your employees and really value them
pros: Solid company with many employee benefits
cons: The company is incredibly ambitious and greedy. They have eliminated many things to make the employees feel appreciated from coffee, water coffee pots and even essentials in the break room for the employees to keep clean to team building activities funds, employee of the month incentives, anniversary bonuses or gifts, parties, awards. Although they are a bank, they don’t keep their own employees being flexible in credit solutions for the employees to enjoy financial products as well. They simply don’t care for recognition at all or helping the employee grown in any way. However, focus on what you are not doing to their satisfaction. You are always criticized and pressured. You spend whole days without taking lunch (they were sued by former employees for it) they overwork and mistreat employees as they only care for customers to be seen and not for employees to have a healthy work environment. This is the reason for many employees taking FMLA and banking center being consistently understaffed.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Work-life balance, Engagement in community services, Taking care of employees in every direction possible and providing extended support during the global pandemic.

It becomes challenging for employees to even retrieve their own payment information. Career advancement is slower than the industry that has adopted a simplified hierarchical structure.
